db:info.db:title: QScopedArrayPointer Class
db:info.db:subtitle: template <typename T, typename Cleanup = QScopedPointerArrayDeleter<T>> class QScopedArrayPointer

db:abstract.db:para: The QScopedArrayPointer class stores a pointer to a dynamically allocated array of objects, and deletes it upon destruction.

db:note.db:para: All functions in this class are reentrant.

db:section.db:title: Detailed Description
db:section.db:para: A QScopedArrayPointer is a QScopedPointer that defaults to deleting the object it is pointing to with the delete[] operator. It also features operator[] for convenience, so we can write:

db:section.db:title: [explicit] QScopedArrayPointer::QScopedArrayPointer(D *p)
db:section.db:para: Constructs a QScopedArrayPointer and stores the array of objects pointed to by p.

db:section.db:title: T &QScopedArrayPointer::operator[](qsizetype i)
db:section.db:para: Provides access to entry i of the scoped pointer's array of objects.
If the contained pointer is nullptr, behavior is undefined.

db:note.db:para: In Qt versions prior to 6.5, i was of type int, not qsizetype, possibly causing truncation on 64-bit platforms.

db:section.db:title: [noexcept, deprecated in 6.2] void QScopedArrayPointer::swap(QScopedArrayPointer<T, Cleanup> &other)
db:section.db:para: This function is deprecated since 6.2. We strongly advise against using it in new code.
Use std::unique_ptr instead; this function may let a pointer escape its scope.
Swaps this pointer with other. This operation is very fast and never fails.
